title: Research Interests
text:
1. Nanotechnology-Enhanced Probiotic Delivery and Therapy
Traditional probiotic delivery faces significant obstacles: degradation in the harsh gastric environment, poor colonization efficiency, and limited therapeutic reach to target sites. Conventional formulations often fail to deliver viable organisms at therapeutic doses where they‚Äôre needed most.

Key Research Questions

Protective encapsulation: Can we engineer biocompatible nanoparticle coatings that shield probiotics from gastric acid while maintaining viability?
Targeted delivery: How can we leverage nanoparticle surface modifications to achieve site-specific probiotic colonization in the GI tract?
Monitoring and tracking: Can radiopaque nanoparticles enable real-time imaging of probiotic distribution and retention in vivo?
Synergistic therapeutics: Do nanoparticle-probiotic combinations enhance therapeutic efficacy compared to conventional delivery methods?

title: Research Interests
section: 2. Reproductive Health: Vaginal and Uterine Microbiome Dynamics
text:
2. Reproductive Health: Vaginal and Uterine Microbiome Dynamics
The vaginal and uterine microbiomes play critical but poorly understood roles in reproductive health, pregnancy outcomes, and gynecological diseases. Unlike gut microbiome research, reproductive tract microbiology remains understudied, with significant gaps in understanding composition, temporal dynamics, and host-microbe interactions across diverse populations.

Key Research Questions

Baseline characterization: What constitutes a ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù vaginal and uterine microbiome across different life stages, ethnicities, and geographic populations?
Temporal dynamics: How do microbial communities change throughout the menstrual cycle, pregnancy, and postpartum period?
Disease associations: Can we identify microbial signatures predictive of conditions such as preterm birth, recurrent pregnancy loss, endometriosis, or infertility?
Mechanistic insights: What host factors (immune, hormonal, genetic) drive microbial community structure and stability?
Intervention strategies: How do common clinical interventions (antibiotics, hormones, assisted reproductive technologies) impact reproductive microbiomes?

title: Research Interests
text:
3. Artificial Intelligence in Microbiome Research

The Challenge
Microbiome datasets are inherently complex‚Äîhigh-dimensional, compositional, temporally dynamic, expensive, and confounded by numerous host and environmental factors. Traditional approaches often fail to capture nonlinear relationships, multi-way interactions, and predictive patterns hidden within these rich datasets. With the rising of AI, we can leverage machine learning methods to extract meaningful insights from microbiome data and move beyond descriptive analyses toward predictive modeling and mechanistic understanding. This includes both supervised learning for outcome prediction and unsupervised methods for pattern discovery.


Key Research Questions

Predictive modeling: Can machine learning algorithms predict clinical outcomes (e.g., oral mucositis severity, treatment response) from baseline microbiome profiles?
Pattern recognition: What hidden microbial community structures emerge from unsupervised clustering and dimensionality reduction approaches?
Feature selection: Which microbial taxa, metabolic pathways, or community network properties are most informative for clinical prediction?
Temporal modeling: Can recurrent neural networks or time-series models capture dynamic microbiome trajectories and predict future states?
Integration frameworks: How can we integrate multi-omics data (microbiome + host genomics + metabolomics + clinical data) using AI to build comprehensive predictive models?
Interpretability: Can we develop explainable AI approaches that provide mechanistic insights, not just black-box predictions?

section: Paper 1: Understanding Oral Mucositis Through Omics Approaches
text:
Paper 1: Understanding Oral Mucositis Through Omics Approaches

Why It Matters
Oral mucositis significantly impacts patient quality of life and can lead to treatment interruptions, potentially compromising cancer outcomes. By understanding the molecular mechanisms through omics, we can move toward precision medicine approaches that identify at-risk patients and develop targeted interventions before severe symptoms develop.


Key Findings

Multi-omics integration: Combined analysis of genetic, microbial, and metabolic data provides the most comprehensive understanding of mucositis pathophysiology
Predictive potential: Several omics markers show promise for identifying patients at high risk for severe mucositis
Research gaps: Highlighted the need for longitudinal studies and standardized methodologies across omics platforms






Oral mucositis is a heregeneous phenotype. An integrated omics approach to understand, prevent, and mitigate oral mucositis is necessary.

section: Paper 2: Novel Absorbable Inferior Vena Cava Filter (IVC) with Tungsten Nanoparticle Infusion
text:
Paper 2: Novel Absorbable Inferior Vena Cava Filter (IVC) with Tungsten Nanoparticle Infusion

Why It Matters
Traditional permanent IVC filters prevent life-threatening blood clots but carry long-term complications, while retrievable filters often cannot be removed. The absorbable filter made of polydioxanone with radiopaque tungsten nanoparticle infusion eliminates the need for a retrieval procedure while maintaining radiopacity for tracking throughout its lifecycle, potentially improving patient safety and reducing healthcare costs for the 200,000+ IVC filter procedures performed annually.


Key Findings

Enhanced visibility: Tungsten nanoparticle infusion provided superior radiopacity compared to standard polymer materials
Safe absorption: Complete biodegradation within expected timeframe with no adverse tissue reactions
Clinical translation potential: Image-guided deployment and monitoring demonstrated feasibility for clinical use

title: Curiosity Over Conflict
text:
Like many good discoveries, mine began as homework. Reading ‚ÄúHow to Be a Modern Scientist‚Äù by Dr.¬†Jeffrey Leek challenged many assumptions I had about what it means to be a scientist‚Äîespecially in today‚Äôs fast-paced, data-saturated world shaped by the internet.
The book brought to mind a previous experience when a post about genetically modified crops sparked a heated debate on social media. At first, participants exchanged thoughtful comments about food safety, sustainability, and agricultural ethics. But as opinions diverged, facts gave way to frustration. The focus shifted from evidence to identity, who was ‚Äúfor‚Äù or ‚Äúagainst‚Äù the science, and revealing how quickly productive dialogue can unravel online. What began as an informative discussion among educated people soon devolved into personal attacks. Though I wasn‚Äôt directly involved, witnessing the exchange made me question my own willingness to engage publicly on complex topics. As scientists, we‚Äôre trained to critique ideas, not people, yet that principle often gets lost in the fast-moving rhythm of online discourse. For a while, the experience discouraged me from posting anything, whether personal or professional, on social media. Still, part of me knew that stepping back entirely wasn‚Äôt the answer and I have to maximize the benefits for science communication through the internet.
That is why I especially appreciated Dr.¬†Leek‚Äôs guidance on responding to criticism. He encourages approaching feedback with curiosity rather than defensiveness‚Äîtaking time to understand where criticism comes from instead of rushing to counter it. His perspective reframed communication for me: it‚Äôs not about winning an argument, but about fostering mutual understanding grounded in respect and evidence. The entire book served as a reminder of my responsibility to communicate science clearly and effectively, and in our digital age, that means engaging thoughtfully online, even when it feels uncomfortable.
Moving forward, I want to practice approaching difficult conversations about science with patience and openness. Every critique offers a chance to clarify, educate, or simply listen. In this time when trust in science feels very fragile, I believe how we respond may matter just as much as what we discover.

Hi! I‚Äôm Erin, a Research Assistant in the Department of Dermatology with a focus on microbiome-centered clinical research. I‚Äôm passionate about understanding how microbial communities influence our health and how evidence-based interventions can improve patient outcomes. I currently support multi-site clinical studies involving pro- and postbiotic nutraceuticals and gastrointestinal health in both healthy and diseased populations..
My background spans microbiology, molecular biology, and nanotechnology. My path to microbiome science began with nanomedicine‚Äîdeveloping image-guided medical devices at MD Anderson Cancer Center, where I worked on radiopaque nanoparticle-embedded polymers for interventional radiology. This foundation in translational research sparked my interest in how we can engineer solutions at the intersection of materials science and biology. I then transitioned to studying the oral and gut microbiome in cancer patients, investigating how microbial communities influence treatment side effects like oral mucositis in head and neck cancer. Our work with oral microbiome made me realize that the microbiome is not just a passive bystander, but an active contributor to clinical outcomes and can be modulated to improve patient experiences.
My primary career goal is to develop innovative therapeutic strategies and advance precision medicine by combining my nanomedicine background with microbiome science.
